newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean opposition backs Kim's bid to save economy.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean opposition backs Kim's bid to save economy.

text.p: South Korean opposition leaders on Tuesday agreed to bury political differences to support President Kim Young-sam's bid to revive an economy hit hard by a loans scandal and labour strife.
In a rare display of solidarity, Kim and the heads of two major opposition groups issued a seven-point agreement pledging joint efforts to overcome economic woes.
The agreement said a special parliamentary investigation and state prosecutors must reveal the whole truth behind a bribes-for-loans scandal involving failed Hanbo Steel Co.
But it added: "We share the view that this issue should no longer pose a hurdle in the development of our economy."

Kim Dae-jung of the main opposition National Congress for New Politics and King Jong-pil of the United Liberal Democrats agreed with the president that a political crisis over the scandal had caused public anxiety.
"In view of the current political situation, ruling and opposition parties will concentrate on reviving the economy and appeal to the people to share hardships," the agreement said.

Government economists say hopes for an economic turnaround this year have been dashed by wildcat strikes in January in protest at a controversial labour bill and the collapse of Hanbo Steel, the country's second largest steelmaker.
The government has revised downward its projection for this year's economic growth to 5.5 percent from an earlier forecast 6.4 percent.
This compares with growth of 7.1 percent in 1996 and 8.9 percent the previous year.

The opposition parties and President Kim's ruling New Korea Party agreed to form a special economic committee, which will also include representatives from various social groups, to deal with economic problems.
They also agreed to speed up banking reforms to prevent any repeat of the Hanbo crisis. Hanbo folded under debts of $5.8 billion provided by banks that did not secure enough collateral.
"Our economy which was once an envy of the world is now pushed to the back in a race of global competition," the political leaders said in a joint statement.
"Now is the time to join all forces to revive the economy."
The political leaders' meeting coincided with the release of figures showing the March trade deficit at $1.88 billion, a sharp jump from a shortfall of $446 million a year earlier.

The figure brought to $7.43 billion South Korea's trade deficit in the first three months of this year, representing more than half the $14 billion deficit targeted by the government for all of this year.
"The most urgent task is to restore confidence by resolving public suspicions over the Hanbo incident and other pressing issues," the statement said.
Ten people, including a former cabinet minister, and close associates of President Kim, are standing trial on bribery and embezzlement charges over the Hanbo scandal.
Prosecutors said they were also probing rumours of a kickback involving the president's second son, Hyun-chul, over a Hanbo deal.
